Subjective: Stress-related symptoms: muscle tension, rapid breathing, palpitations. Correlates with demanding job as new internal medicine doctor. Feeling unsure, overwhelmed by understaffing, long shifts. Difficulty saying no, feeling guilty when unable to help colleagues. Symptoms occur during rest (bath, bedtime), sometimes during work (toilet). Palpitations noticeable in neck, regular but fast. Rapid breathing feels like shortness of breath. Symptoms daily for 2 weeks, gradually worsening over months. Affects sleep, difficulty falling asleep due to worrying about next day. Sleeps ~6 hours/night. Better sleep on days off. Works ~38 hrs/week, often longer days. Symptoms last ~30 mins, resolve spontaneously. No chest pain. No dizziness/lightheadedness. No abdominal complaints. Support system: lives with doctor housemates, many doctor friends/colleagues. Request: Rule out physical causes (e.g., anemia), discuss with professional (practice nurse). Worried about health despite knowing it's temporary phase.
Objective: Vitals: BP 120/60, HR 65, O2 sat 98%, RR 14. Lungs: clear, good breath sounds bilaterally. Heart: normal sounds, no murmurs. Physical exam otherwise unremarkable.
Assessment: Stress reaction with somatic symptoms, likely related to occupational overload. Rule out anemia, thyroid dysfunction, renal/hepatic issues. No evidence of cardiac arrhythmia or significant pulmonary pathology on exam.
Plan:
1. Blood test: CBC (hemoglobin), TSH, LFTs, RFTs to rule out somatic causes. 
2. Refer to mental health nurse practitioner for counseling, appointment can be made today. 
3. Lifestyle advice: Actively build in relaxation moments, engage in energy-giving activities (coffee, call friend, walk, swim). Maintain regularity (sleep/wake times). 
4. Consider consulting occupational health service at hospital for schedule adjustment advice. 
5. Follow up: Check blood test results in 2 working days via portal or phone. Return if symptoms worsen or concerns arise. 
6. Safety netting: Return if symptoms worsen, increased worry.
